response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The S.D. 2 version of the measure aims to consolidate and centralize government functions relating to broadband internet access. [CHUNK_199] A key amendment in this version is transferring the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the Broadband Office. [CHUNK_205] This version also inserts language to clarify the effect that the transfer of the Broadband Office will have on the continuity of rules, policies, and documents. [CHUNK_206]",
  "appropriations": "The legislative document appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [CHUNK_174] The legislative document also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) out of the broadband revolving fund for fiscal year 2025-2026 for the reimbursement of contracts executed by the broadband office. [CHUNK_175] An additional appropriation with a blank amount is included for fiscal year 2025-2026 for the establishment of an unspecified number of full-time equivalent digital navigator positions. [CHUNK_177]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The Department of Budget and Finance (B&F) does not support the creation of any revolving fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.4, HRS, which includes the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. [CHUNK_7] [CHUNK_9] Regarding H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1, B&F states it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [CHUNK_10]",
  "agency_impact": "The Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism states that the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) has provided steady leadership in state broadband and digital equity and that DBEDT will continue to collaborate with the Office. [CHUNK_51] [CHUNK_52] The Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs requests an amendment to consolidate the duty of collecting and posting broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Section 2 of Act 151, SLH 2011, from the Department to the HBDEO/Broadband Office. [CHUNK_16] [CHUNK_17] The Office of Enterprise Technology Services notes it will incur additional operational and administrative costs associated with moving HBDEO’s staff and services under its division. [CHUNK_64]",
  "economic_impact": "",
  "policy_impact": "The measure has been amended to transfer the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, as amended, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the Broadband Office. [CHUNK_205] This version also inserts language that clarifies the effect that the transfer of the Broadband Office will have on the continuity of rules, policies, and documents. [CHUNK_205] Testimony was received requesting the removal of language that excludes the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service, arguing that it could prevent small, innovative projects in remote, unserved or underserved communities. [CHUNK_95] [CHUNK_105]",
  "revenue_sources": "The Department of Budget and Finance states that as a matter of general policy, it does not support the creation of any revolving fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.4, HRS, including the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. [CHUNK_7] [CHUNK_9] Regarding this bill, the department finds it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [CHUNK_10]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "According to testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS), the HBDEO’s original request in the upcoming fiscal 2025-2027 biennium budget was based on a current budget of $360,000 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) to fund four staff and operating expenses. [CHUNK_60] The testimony indicates HBDEO has been operating with essentially no operating expenses for the past two fiscal years. [CHUNK_61] The HBDEO had asked for $777,090 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 26 with $452,302 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for personal services, and $324,788 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for other expenses. [CHUNK_62] ETS asks that the HBDEO be funded with this amount in the FB2025-2027 biennium budget. [CHUNK_63] ETS also states that without proper funding, moving the HBDEO to DAGS-ETS would negatively impact critical services. [CHUNK_64] The S.D. 2 version appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) in general revenues for FY 2025-2026 to be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [CHUNK_174] It also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) from the broadband revolving fund in FY 2025-2026 for the reimbursement of contracts executed by the broadband office. [CHUNK_175] ETS will also incur additional operational and administrative costs associated with moving HBDEO’s staff and services under its division. [CHUNK_64]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "Testimony from the Waianae Coast Comprehensive Health Center expresses concern with language in the bill under the Broadband Revolving Fund for \"Supporting broadband projects, excluding the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service\". [CHUNK_94] The Center requests the removal of the exclusionary language to restore the bill’s original intent, arguing the added language conflicts with the State’s objectives and policies. [CHUNK_95] Other testimony claims possible interpretations of this language could prevent even small, innovative projects in remote, unserved or underserved communities. [CHUNK_105]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "Testimony from the University of Hawai‘i supports the establishment of the Hawai‘i Broadband Revolving Fund to ensure funds are used to support long term sustainability of the state's broadband infrastructure assets. [CHUNK_81] However, the Department of Budget and Finance states that it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [CHUNK_10]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "The bill has been amended to S.D. 2, which transfers the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the new Broadband Office. [CHUNK_205] This version also adds language clarifying the continuity of rules, policies, and documents after the transfer. [CHUNK_206] New testimony from the Department of Budget and Finance expresses concern over the long-term self-sustainability of the proposed Broadband Revolving Fund. [CHUNK_10] Additional testimony provides more detailed opposition to the bill's language excluding the use of the revolving fund for the provision of retail service infrastructure. [CHUNK_95] [CHUNK_105]"
}

WRITTEN ONLY TESTIMONY BY LUIS P. SALAVERIA DIRECTOR, DEPARTMENT OF BUDGET AND FINANCE TO THE SENATE COMMITTEE ON WAYS AND MEANS ON HOUSE BILL NO. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1 April 1, 2025 10:01 a.m. Room 211 and Videoconference RELATING TO THE HAWAII BROADBAND AND DIGITAL EQUITY OFFICE The Department

TO THE HAWAII BROADBAND AND DIGITAL EQUITY OFFICE The Department of Budget and Finance (B&F) offers comments on this bill. House Bill (H.B.) No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1: 1) establishes the Broadband Office (BO) within the Office of Enterprise Technology Services; 2) establishes the Broadband Revolving Fund (BRF) to

Technology Services; 2) establishes the Broadband Revolving Fund (BRF) to be administered by BO for the purposes of supporting broadband projects, defraying the cost of internet services, and funding positions for personnel to provide technical assistance for the community; 3) repeals Chapter 206S, HRS, Section 440G-11.5, HRS, and Section 3

repeals Chapter 206S, HRS, Section 440G-11.5, HRS, and Section 3 of Act 199, SLH 2010, as amended by Section 5 of Act 151, SLH 2011, as amended by Section 2 of Act 23, SLH 2016; 4) appropriates $200,000 in general funds for FY 26 to be deposited into the BRF;

funds for FY 26 to be deposited into the BRF; 5) appropriates $200,000 out of the BRF for FY 26 for reimbursement of contracts executed by BO; and 6) appropriates an unspecified amount out of the BRF for FY 26 for the establishment of an unspecified number of digital navigator

for the establishment of an unspecified number of digital navigator positions. As a matter of general policy, B&F does not support the creation of any revolving fund, which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.4, HRS. Revolving funds -2- should: 1) serve a need as demonstrated by the purpose,

should: 1) serve a need as demonstrated by the purpose, scope of work, and an explanation why the program cannot be implemented successfully under the general fund appropriation process; 2) reflect a clear nexus between the benefits sought and charges made upon the users or beneficiaries or a clear link

made upon the users or beneficiaries or a clear link between the program and the sources of revenue; 3) provide an appropriate means of financing for the program or activity; and 4) demonstrate the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. Regarding H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1, it is difficult

H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1, it is difficult to determine whether the BRF would be self-sustaining. Thank you for your consideration of our comments. STATE OF HAWAII | KA MOKUʻĀINA ʻO HAWAIʻI OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR DEPARTMENT OF COMMERCE AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS KA ʻOIHANA PILI KĀLEPA 335 MERCHANT

and Members of the Committee: My name is Randy Leong, and I am the Cable Television Administrator of the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs’ (“Department”) Cable Television Division. of this bill is to transfer the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services, rename the HBDEO to Broadband Office, repeal broadband duties assigned to the

HBDEO to Broadband Office, repeal broadband duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, repeal the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council, establish the Broadband Revolving Fund, establish positions, and appropriate funds. attachment, pg.3, line 21). This little-used provision requires the Department to post online notices of certain actions relating to broadband infrastructure on existing utility poles and conduits which use existing infrastructure and facilities. The online notices are for expedited projects which are exempt from county and state permitting and approval

which are exempt from county and state permitting and approval requirements, so long as 30-days’ notice is provided in advance. The Department finds it prudent and beneficial to conserve taxpayer resources by consolidating broadband and related duties under one state agency. This would also reduce confusion by having one state

agency. This would also reduce confusion by having one state office in which the public can be referred to and contact for broadband issues and matters. Due to changes in broadband infrastructure funding and public policy in recent years, the Department has occupied a secondary role to other state agencies

Department has occupied a secondary role to other state agencies who are leading broadband infrastructure development and digital equity initiatives. 2 of Act 151, as amended, from the Department to the HBDEO/Broadband Office. The Department defers to the other agencies regarding the other sections of this bill which affect those agencies. Dela Cruz, Chair Senate Committee on Ways and Means The Thirty-Third Legislature State Capitol State of Hawai῾i Honolulu, Hawai'i 96813 Dear Senator Dela Cruz, and Committee members SUBJECT: HB934 HD1 SD1 Relating to the Hawai’i Broadband and Digital Equity Office

SD1 Relating to the Hawai’i Broadband and Digital Equity Office The Hawai῾i State Council on Developmental Disabilities SUPPORTS HB934 HD1 SD1, which transfers the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of

the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services. Renames the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office to Broadband Office. Repeals broadband duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs. Repeals the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council. Establishes the Broadband Revolving Fund. Establishes positions.

Assistance Advisory Council. Establishes the Broadband Revolving Fund. Establishes positions. Appropriates funds. Effective 7/1/3000. (SD1) Access to broadband and digital technology is critical for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) to fully participate in society. Reliable internet connectivity and digital literacy are essential for accessing telehealth services, engaging in

digital literacy are essential for accessing telehealth services, engaging in educational opportunities, securing employment, and participating in community life. HB934 HD1 SD1 strengthens the State's infrastructure to ensure digital equity, especially for underserved and vulnerable populations. The proposed restructuring and the establishment of the special fund will enhance the State’s

the establishment of the special fund will enhance the State’s ability to develop and implement strategies to improve broadband access and affordability. The emphasis on supporting broadband projects, and funding positions for technical assistance aligns with the needs of the I/DD community, which often faces significant barriers to digital inclusion.

I/DD community, which often faces significant barriers to digital inclusion. Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony in support of HB934 HD1 SD1. is to consolidate and centralize government functions relating to broadband internet access. Specifically, this measure: (1) Renames the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office as the Broadband Office and transfers the office from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services; (2) Repeals

Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services; (2) Repeals broadband duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs; (3) Repeals the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council; (4) Establishes positions; and (5) Makes appropriations. Your Committee received written comments in support of this measure from the Office of the

in support of this measure from the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, University of Hawaii System, Hawaii State Council on Developmental Disabilities, Charter Communications, Waianae Coast Comprehensive Health Center, and two individuals. Your Committee received written comments on this measure from the Department of

received written comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance; Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism; and Office of Enterprise Technology Services. Your Committee finds that it would be prudent and beneficial to consolidate broadband internet access and related duties under a single agency. This consolidation

access and related duties under a single agency. This consolidation would reduce confusion by having a single state office to which the public can be referred and contact regarding broadband issues and matters. (SD1) Access to broadband and digital technology is critical for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) to fully participate in society. Reliable internet connectivity and digital literacy are essential for accessing telehealth services, engaging in

digital literacy are essential for accessing telehealth services, engaging in educational opportunities, securing employment, and participating in community life. HB934 HD1 SD1 strengthens the State's infrastructure to ensure digital equity, especially for underserved and vulnerable populations. The proposed restructuring and the establishment of the special fund will enhance the State’s

the establishment of the special fund will enhance the State’s ability to develop and implement strategies to improve broadband access and affordability. The emphasis on supporting broadband projects, and funding positions for technical assistance aligns with the needs of the I/DD community, which often faces significant barriers to digital inclusion.

I/DD community, which often faces significant barriers to digital inclusion. Thank you for the opportunity to submit testimony in support of HB934 HD1 SD1. and members of the committee: The Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS) humbly offers comments on this bill that transfers the Hawaiʻi Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and

of Enterprise Technology Services in the Department of Accounting and General Services (DAGS), establishes the Broadband Revolving Fund, and appropriates funds. ETS strongly supports Connect Kākou, led by Governor Josh Green and Lieutenant Governor Sylvia Luke, to ensure that every resident of Hawaiʻi has access to broadband Internet – plus

resident of Hawaiʻi has access to broadband Internet – plus the skills and devices they need to use the Internet for economic, social, and community prosperity. Assuming the responsibility of managing the HBDEO is a significant task for ETS. Presently, ETS is dedicated to internal government functions such as enterprise

ETS is dedicated to internal government functions such as enterprise IT governance, cybersecurity, data governance and sharing, and supporting the state's major modernization initiatives. SSCR1752 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1752 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 934 H.D. 1 S.D. 2 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Ways and Means, to which was referred H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1,

Means, to which was referred H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE HAWAII BROADBAND AND DIGITAL EQUITY OFFICE," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to consolidate and centralize government functions relating to broadband

is to consolidate and centralize government functions relating to broadband internet access. Specifically, this measure: (1) Renames the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office as the Broadband Office and transfers the office from the Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services; (2) Repeals

Tourism to the Office of Enterprise Technology Services; (2) Repeals broadband duties assigned to the Director of Commerce and Consumer Affairs; (3) Repeals the Broadband Assistance Advisory Council; (4) Establishes positions; and (5) Makes appropriations. Your Committee received written comments in support of this measure from the Office of the

in support of this measure from the Office of the Lieutenant Governor, Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs, University of Hawaii System, Hawaii State Council on Developmental Disabilities, Charter Communications, Waianae Coast Comprehensive Health Center, and two individuals. Your Committee received written comments on this measure from the Department of

received written comments on this measure from the Department of Budget and Finance; Department of Business, Economic Development, and Tourism; and Office of Enterprise Technology Services. Your Committee finds that it would be prudent and beneficial to consolidate broadband internet access and related duties under a single agency. This consolidation

access and related duties under a single agency. This consolidation would reduce confusion by having a single state office to which the public can be referred and contact regarding broadband issues and matters.
